Articles.Content:
I used KSP to model a launch for a discussion elsewhere and I don't understand the results at all.

A simple rocket, I messed with MechJeb's ascent guidance to get a launch straight up to an apoapsis at 80Mm.

Now,  the rocket had a horizontal velocity imparted by Kerbin that was 7x what MechJeb says is needed to avoid the atmosphere--huh??  Why am I on a lithobraking trajectory at all?  I see nothing that should have robbed me of Kerbin's rotational velocity, I should still have this at apoapsis.

(Note:  I first tried this with SAS--it can't hold straight up adequately.  Likewise, by hand I can't, either.)

Yeah, there tends to be a tiny yaw. I launch almost all my ships straight up, and they all do tend to drift a tiny bit retrograde (west). So my ascents tend to be a little more vertical than one might expect, because the drift counteracts Kerbin's initial rotational velocity during the burn. I use the effect to fine-tune my Mun/Minmus intercepts.
